awd_titl_txt: Tapping outstanding new lake records of annual- to millennial-scale Holocene climate variability in the north Pacific region
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding climate variability over a wide range of timescales is a primary objective of climate science research because it is likely to improve our ability to foresee future climate. The investigators will document past (Holocene = 12,000 years) climate changes on time scales ranging from annual to millennial using evidence from sediments stored in lakes around Anchorage, Alaska, where climate closely tracks the broader North Pacific region. In addition, the sedimentary records contain information about: (1) ash-fall hazards from Cook Inlet volcanoes, (2) the magnitude and frequency of major earthquakes, (3) changes in glacier meltwater input to Eklutna Lake, a major source of electricity and freshwater for Anchorage, and (4) long-term environmental variability, which serves as a baseline reference for recent ecosystem changes. The project will support early-career scientists and will train graduate and undergraduate students.

This study will take advantage of the best annually laminated (varved) sediment -- among the most valuable sources of proxy climate data -- ever recovered from Alaska. Fluctuations in varve thickness and grain size of sediments recovered from the glacier-fed study lakes reflect major hydroclimate changes. In addition, new sediment cores from non-glacial lakes will provide a multi-proxy approach to understanding how shifts in the mean state of climate during the Holocene were associated with changes in north Pacific climate variability.

por.por_cntn:
Tapping outstanding new lake records of annual- to millennial-scale Holocene climate variability in the north Pacific region

Understanding climate variability over a wide range of timescales is a primary objective of climate science research because it is likely to improve our ability to foresee future climate, including long-term climate changes that respond to both natural and human forces. This project focused on south-central Alaska, where climate changes closely track those of the broader North Pacific. This includes the influence of ocean-atmospheric circulation associated with the Aleutian Low. Sediment collected from six lakes was analyzed for a variety of physical and biogeochemical indicators of past glacier and hydroclimate changes. Two distinct types of lakes were studied for their complementary information:

(1) Sediment cores from three glacier-fed lakes (Eklutna, Skilak and Pothole Lakes) were used to reconstruct the history of glacier fluctuations at century scale, extending back 2300 years. Results show that glaciers were large around 320 BCE and retreated by 270 BCE. They remained relatively small until they expanded again around 1600 CE. This Little Ice Age advance was the most prolonged interval of sustained glacier growth during the past 2300 years. Evidence for a major shift in the glacial-fluvial system was discovered at Pothole Lake, which is situated at the mouth of a tributary valley adjacent to the margin of the Skilak Glacier outwash plain. Around 1650 CE, the outwash aggraded by at least 32 m in less than two centuries to impound Pothole Lake. This pronounced advance was likely caused by the cumulative effects of millennial-scale decrease in summer insolation at northern high latitude, increased downturns in global radiative forcing associated with lower solar and volcanic activity, and increased winter precipitation resulting from a strong Aleutian Low.

(2) Three lowland lakes (Sunken Island, Kelly and Hidden Lakes) were studied to interpret past hydroclimate changes at millennial scale, extending back over 14,000 years. Prior to around 8000 years ago, deposition at Kelly Lake was dominated by authigenic carbonate, which fluctuated with the relative proportion of groundwater-fed solutes. Results support a growing body of evidence that the Aleutian Low strengthened between the middle and late Holocene (around 5000 to 4000 years ago). This project found that this shift occurred along with an increase in the annual duration and extent of sea ice in the western Arctic Ocean. This finding indicates that the observed modern relationship between North Pacific atmospheric circulation and high latitude hydroclimate is a persistent feature of the coupled ocean-atmosphere system.

The results of this project highlight: (1) the benefits of combining proxy data and models to interpret water isotope data in terms of past hydroclimate variability; (2) the utility of a multi-site, multi-proxy approach for gaining a holistic understanding of past hydrologic and environmental change; (3) the importance of groundwater, precipitation, and atmospheric circulation patterns as influences on lake water isotope composition, depending on a given lake?s environmental setting; (4) the relevance of both of site-specific responses and regional or synoptic climate phenomena to lake-sediment-based paleoenvironmental data; and (5) the importance of examining climate and environmental change on a range of timescales (e.g., interannual and multi-millennial) to achieve a more holistic understanding of past climate variability.

The sedimentary records from these lakes also contributed to a better understanding of regional volcanic and earthquake hazards, and long-term environmental variability, which serves as a baseline reference for land mangers striving to contextualize recent ecosystem changes. The project generated nine peer-reviewed journal articles, and one is under review. Datasets associated with the published studies are available through public data archives. Twelve abstracts were presented at professional meetings. As part of this project, graduate and undergraduate students in STEM fields received in-depth scientific training. This project provided the primary support for three graduate students (one PhD and two MSc), all of whom have graduated. All are women, including one person of color.
